author: Somudranil Sarkar
title: Moscow, Athens, Vienna, and Warsaw-bound flights face new cancellations at Zvartnots International Airport
text:
Bad weather conditions, including heavy fog and low visibility, have caused significant disruptions at Zvartnots International Airport in Yerevan, Armenia. Several flights to Moscow, Athens, Vienna and Warsaw have been canceled or delayed, leading to rerouted landings and widespread inconvenience for passengers. Lusine Moghrovyan, the airport’s spokesperson, confirmed that flights from Athens, Warsaw, and Vienna were redirected to Tbilisi, while others landed in alternative destinations such as Makhachkala and Nizhny Novgorod. The situation underlines the vulnerability of global travel to weather-related disruptions and highlights its impact on the travel industry.
Cancellations and Delays in Numbers The bad weather resulted in a substantial number of delays and cancellations for both arrivals and departures. Below is a summary of the affected flights.
Arrivals Airline Origin Flight No. Scheduled Arrival Actual Arrival Status RED WINGS Sochi WZ 4329 13/12 14:00 13/12 16:35 Delay FLYONE ARM Moscow 3F 316 13/12 15:30 13/12 21:40 Delay Kaluga KLF A4 4009 13/12 18:45 13/12 21:00 Delay Departures Airline Destination Flight No. Scheduled Departure Gate Actual Departure Status AEGEAN Athens A3 899 13/12 05:20 Cancelled AUSTRIAN Vienna OS 642 13/12 05:45 Cancelled POLISH LOT Warsaw LO 730 13/12 06:40 Cancelled FLYONE ARM Moscow 3F 315 13/12 08:00 1-4 13/12 13:30 Delay WIZZ AIR W6 Larnaca W6 4550 13/12 10:40 69-72 13/12 13:20 Delay The Impact on Travelers The weather-induced disruptions have left many travelers stranded or forced to adjust their plans. Flights redirected to alternative airports, such as Tbilisi, Makhachkala, and Nizhny Novgorod, create logistical challenges for passengers needing to connect to onward destinations. Delays of several hours also complicate schedules, with passengers needing to rebook or wait for clearer conditions to travel.
For many, these disruptions mean unexpected expenses for accommodations, meals, and alternative transportation. The lack of clarity on rescheduled flights can exacerbate frustrations among passengers, highlighting the critical need for effective communication during such crises.
Effects on the Travel Industry Flight cancellations and delays have broader implications for the travel industry. Airlines operating in and out of Yerevan face operational challenges, including increased costs for rerouting and passenger accommodation. Similarly, travel agencies and tourism operators dependent on smooth flight operations experience disruptions in their itineraries, impacting customer satisfaction.
Broader Industry Impacts: Increased Costs: Airlines face additional expenses for rerouting, fuel, and passenger care. Customer Dissatisfaction: Delays lead to negative experiences, impacting airline ratings. Tourism Revenue Loss: Reduced connectivity could affect local tourism-dependent businesses. Global Implications The disruptions at Zvartnots Airport demonstrate how weather conditions at one location can affect the global travel network. Travelers from major hubs such as Vienna, Moscow, and Warsaw face complications, with ripple effects impacting connections to Europe, Asia, and beyond. These challenges highlight the importance of robust contingency plans and real-time communication between airlines and passengers.
For travelers, such disruptions emphasize the value of comprehensive travel insurance that covers unexpected delays and cancellations. It also underscores the importance of flexible itineraries and staying informed about potential weather-related issues.
Recommendations for Travelers To navigate disruptions like those at Yerevan’s airport, travelers can take several proactive measures:
Monitor Flight Updates: Use airline apps or official websites to stay informed. Prepare for Delays: Carry essentials like snacks, medications, and chargers in hand luggage. Consider Insurance: Ensure travel insurance covers cancellations or delays due to weather. The severe weather conditions affecting Yerevan’s Zvartnots Airport have led to significant flight disruptions, highlighting the vulnerability of air travel to external factors. While airlines and airports work to manage these challenges, the impact on passengers and the travel industry serves as a reminder of the importance of preparedness and adaptability. These disruptions underscore the need for efficient communication and contingency planning, ensuring that both passengers and industry stakeholders can navigate such challenges with minimal inconvenience.

author: Financial Times
title: Saudi Arabia to abandon $100 crude | Financial Post
text: Saudi Arabia ready to abandon $100 crude target to take back market share Oil price falls as kingdom prepares to raise output Article content [Saudi Arabia](https://financialpost.com/tag/saudi-arabia/) is ready to abandon its unofficial price target of US$100 a barrel for crude as it prepares to increase output, in a sign that the kingdom is resigned to a period of lower [oil prices](https://financialpost.com/tag/oil-price/), according to people familiar with the country’s thinking. [tap here to see other videos from our team](/video-centre/). Saudi Arabia ready to abandon $100 crude target to take back market share Back to video The world’s largest oil exporter and seven other members of the [OPEC+ producer group](https://financialpost.com/tag/opec/) had been due to unwind long-standing production cuts from the start of October. But a two-month delay sparked speculation over whether the group would ever be able to raise output, with the price of Brent crude, the international benchmark, briefly dropping below US$70 this month to its lowest since December 2021. However, officials in the kingdom are committed to bringing back that production as planned on Dec. 1, even if it leads to a prolonged period of lower prices, the people said. The prospect of Riyadh ditching its unofficial target hit the price of oil and the shares of oil companies on Thursday. Brent crude was down 3.5 per cent on the day at US$70.87, while [West Texas Intermediate](https://financialpost.com/tag/west-texas-intermediate/), the U.S. benchmark, dropped 3.8 per cent to US$67.06. The declines hit the share prices of Europe’s big oil producers, with BP PLC falling 4.1 per cent, Shell PLC down five per cent and TotalEnergies SE off 3.3 per cent. Saudi Arabia’s energy ministry did not respond to a request for comment. The shift in thinking represents a major change of tack for Saudi Arabia, which has led other OPEC+ members in repeatedly cutting output since November 2022 in an attempt to maintain high prices. The price of Brent averaged US$99 a barrel in 2022, the highest level in eight years, as the fallout from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine roiled markets, but has since fallen back. Increased supply from non-OPEC producers, particularly the United States, and weak demand growth in [China](https://financialpost.com/tag/china/), have reduced the impact of the group’s cuts over time. Brent has averaged US$73 a barrel so far in September, even as Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza has threatened to escalate into a wider regional conflict. Saudi Arabia needs an oil price of close to US$100 a barrel to balance its budget, according to the [International Monetary Fund](https://financialpost.com/tag/international-monetary-fund/), as Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman seeks to fund a series of megaprojects at the heart of an ambitious economic reform program. However, the kingdom has decided it is not willing to continue ceding market share to other producers, the people said. It also believes it has enough alternative funding options to weather a period of lower prices, such as tapping foreign exchange reserves or issuing sovereign debt, they added. A decade ago Saudi Arabia brought the $100 a barrel oil era to a close, increasing output as prices fell in 2014 in an effort to thwart the rapid emergence of the U.S. shale industry. More recently, under energy minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, the kingdom has sought to maximize revenues, cutting production to support prices. However, the policy has at times inflamed tensions with the U.S., which tried and failed to get Riyadh to boost production in 2022 after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sent prices soaring. Saudi Arabia has shouldered the majority of the OPEC+ cuts to date, reducing its own production by two million barrels a day in the past two years, representing over one-third of the cuts by members. The kingdom is currently pumping 8.9 million barrels per day (b/d), the lowest level since 2011, outside of the coronavirus pandemic and the 2019 attack on the state oil company’s processing facility at Abqaiq. Under the delayed plan to begin unwinding the cuts, Saudi Arabia will increase its monthly production by an additional 83,000 b/d each month from December, boosting its output by a total of one million b/d by December 2025. A key frustration for Saudi Arabia has been that several members of the cartel, including Iraq and Kazakhstan, have been partially ignoring the cuts by pumping more than their respective quotas. OPEC secretary-general Haitham Al Ghais visited both countries in August and extracted commitments that they would adjust their future production plans to compensate for past oversupply. But Saudi Arabia remains concerned about compliance and could decide to unwind its own cuts faster than planned if either country does not toe the line, one of the people added. © 2024 The Financial Times Ltd Join the Conversation Postmedia is committed to maintaining a lively but civil forum for discussion. Please keep comments relevant and respectful. Comments may take up to an hour to appear on the site. You will receive an email if there is a reply to your comment, an update to a thread you follow or if a user you follow comments. Visit our [Community Guidelines](/community-guidelines/) for more information.

author: Redacción
title: Juan Espadas, en Huelva: “Es intolerable que Moreno Bonilla haga oídos sordos a los dependientes»
text:
El secretario general del PSOE de Andalucía, Juan Espadas , ha dejado claro que el gobierno de Moreno Bonilla “no puede dar la espalda” a las personas dependientes y a quienes las atienden y ha considerado “intolerable” que siga haciendo “oídos sordos” ante los graves problemas existentes en la prestación del servicio en nuestra comunidad.
“El sábado se lo dirán en la calle. No vamos a parar hasta que Moreno Bonilla reaccione y deje de generar esa profunda de desigualdad con respecto a otros españoles”, ha dicho Juan Espadas en el marco del encuentro mantenido en Huelva con asociaciones de personas con discapacidad, que ha arrancado con un mensaje de apoyo en el Día Mundial del Apolio y del Síndrome Pospolio a todas las personas que padecen esta enfermedad y que necesitan “recursos y más medios”.
“Este sábado vamos a ver en la calle a muchas personas reivindicando su derecho a la dependencia, que no se está cumpliendo por la nefasta gestión que el gobierno de Moreno Bonilla está desarrollando. Andalucía es la última comunidad autónoma con mucha diferencia, con el desgraciado récord en lista de espera media, 609 días, el doble que la segunda región con mayor espera”, ha advertido.
Ante esta situación “intolerable”, Espadas ha subrayado que el PSOE ya se lo ha dicho en el Parlamento, pero este sábado “se lo van a decir los andaluces en la calle”, unas movilizaciones que cuentan con el apoyo socialista. A ello, se une que “los propios empleados públicos, los trabajadores sociales que llevan la dependencia en Andalucía, también están alzando la voz ” para decir que Moreno Bonilla está “atacando ese derecho y poniendo en riesgo la atención a estas personas”.
Con más de 50.000 personas en listas de espera, Juan Espadas ha considerado que se está haciendo “un daño irreversible” a estas personas. Así, llama la atención sobre el hecho de que “Moreno Bonilla no sólo parece que no reacciona, sino que, además, intenta cambiar el modelo para empeorarlo más aún”. En este sentido, ha avisado de que “se está taponando la entrada de nuevas solicitudes, intentando difuminar las listas de espera”. “De forma encubierta, está privatizando también la gestión del servicio”, ha sentenciado.
Igualmente, ha avisado del problema grave existente en las residencias ante la “necesidad de recursos económicos para mantener la viabilidad”, algo ante lo que Moreno Bonilla “se encoge de hombros”. “No se van a poder mantener a partir del 1 de enero el trabajo de las entidades de apoyo a las personas con discapacidad o dependientes porque la Junta de Andalucía se desentiende”, ha añadido, incidiendo en que “el sistema está a punto de colapsar”. Mientras tanto, “Moreno Bonilla reduce los recursos, en vez de aumentarlos como el Gobierno de España, y no se sienta con el sector”, ha lamentado.
Para Juan Espadas, “Moreno Bonilla está dedicado a la confrontación con el Gobierno de España y a reducir impuestos a los más ricos, cuando lo que tiene que cambiar radicalmente son sus prioridades, que ahora mismo son la sanidad pública y debería de ser la dependencia”.
Al respecto, ha avisado de que lo que el gobierno de Moreno Bonilla ha contado de los presupuestos “es exactamente lo mismo que contó el año pasado y el anterior, no hay novedades” pese a la situación existente.
“No prioriza las necesidades en sanidad o dependencia. Moreno Bonilla no parece enterarse de los problemas reales de la gente. Es una auténtica lástima teniendo en cuenta los recursos existentes”, ha manifestado, recordando la paradoja del gobierno del PP que “le ahorra dinero a los más ricos y al día siguiente se queja de que le falta para sanidad o dependencia”.
Por su parte, la secretaria general del PSOE de Huelva, María Eugenia Limón, ha manifestado su preocupación por las reivindicaciones del sector de la dependencia que debido a esa falta de financiación y a la subida del precio/plaza se están viendo abocados a cerrar sus puertas. Así ha asegurado que “Moreno Bonilla es el enemigo número uno de la dependencia, yo creo que eso es algo que todo el mundo sabe, tenemos unos datos que día a día nos están ofreciendo pues tanto las personas que trabajan entidades de la dependencia como las personas que trabajan en las entidades sociales con personas con discapacidad”.

author: Rakhi Jagga
title: ‘Red alert’ to continue in Punjab, Haryana till Saturday morning amid dip in mercury, cold conditions
text:
Cold conditions are likely to continue in Punjab and Haryana in the coming week with the IMD having issued a ‘red alert’ in both the states till 8.30 am on Saturday.
According to the IMD, dense to very dense fog conditions will prevail in 15 of the 23 districts of Punjab and 11 of 22 districts of Haryana.
In Punjab, the ‘red alert’ has been sounded in Amritsar, Taran Taran, Kapurthala,
Jalandhar, Ludhiana, Moga, Barnala, Bathinda, Mansa, Muktsar, Sangrur, Ferozepur, Fazilka, Patiala, Faridkot and Malerkotla.
In Haryana, Ambala, Karnal, Kurukshetra, Kaithal, Rohtak, Sonipat, Panipat, Sirsa, Fatehabad, Hisar and Jind have been put on ‘red alert’.
The IMD has also issued an ‘orange alert’ in both Punjab and Haryana after the end of the ‘red alerts’.
Meanwhile, both the maximum and the minimum temperatures have dipped in the region, leading to cold and dry weather conditions.
In Punjab, the maximum temperature saw a dip of 4.9 degrees Celsius in just 24 hours. On Wednesday, the maximum temperature was recorded at 23.1 degrees Celsius in Pathankot while on Thursday, it dipped to 18.2 degrees Celsius in Bathinda and Faridkot.
Meanwhile, the minimum temperature observed at 8.30 am on Friday was 4.7 degrees Celsius at the Ballowal observatory of Shaheed Bhagat Singh Nagar compared to the 5.6 degrees Celsius temperature on Thursday morning at the same location — thus recording a dip of 1.1 degrees Celsius.
In Haryana, the maximum temperature on Thursday morning was 24 degrees Celsius at the Narnaul observatory of Mahendergarh area which was 0.7 degrees Celsius on the higher side compared to Wednesday at the same place.
The minimum temperature in Haryana on Friday morning at 8.30 am was 7 degrees Celsius at Narnaul compared to 7.1 degrees at Bhiwani 24 hours ago.

author: Diario Libre
title: La entrevista de Ben Affleck que podría aclarar causa de su divorcio - Diario Libre
text:
Sin las reales causas establecidas, las redes sociales siguen llenándose de especulaciones sobre lo que habría desencadenado el cuarto divorcio de Jennifer Lopez, del que se creía el gran amor de su vida, Ben Affleck .
Ahora el protagonista es el actor, cuyas palabras en una antigua entrevista han dado la vuelta al mundo. Y según People en español, arrojan un poco de claridad sobre lo sucedido con su ya expareja.
Aunque, no es de estos días, pero su confesión se podría aplicar perfectamente a este proceso de separación que vive y confirmar una de las razones más fuertes de la ruptura.
"Yo no estoy hecho para ser famoso , no me gusta, te lo puedes quedar. No recibo ningún beneficio de ello más que haberme librado de alguna multa y obtener reservaciones en restaurantes, ¡y no hago fila en Disneyland! Muchos artistas lo desean con todas sus fuerzas porque nadie quiere actuar en una sala vacía, quieren tener esa atención", expresó en esta intervención.
Hay más. "Soy alguien que quiere expresar algo profundo a la gente y que haya gente que responda a eso. Y la celebridad en sí misma, la atención en sí misma no es algo valioso para mí, en lo absoluto".
"Soy tímido , no quiero decirle cosas a la gente, me han criticado tanto en mi vida, malinterpretado, y caracterizado de una forma que me hace sentir incómodo... Quiero hacer mi trabajo, pero no lo que implica ser una celebridad ".
View this post on Instagram A post shared by Acting Tips | Estudio de formacion actoral (@acting__tips)
Más Según People en español, esto fue un aviso claro de lo que estaría por pasar y, desafortunadamente, ocurrió. Te puede interesar Se revela el supuesto motivo por el que Jennifer López le pidió el divorcio a Ben Affleck

author: giorgia.
title: Derrotado por la Juventus, el PSG ya eliminado
text: Condenadas a revertir la situación en casa, las parisinas volvieron a caer en la trampa italiana. Su aventura en la Liga de Campeones termina antes de la fase de grupos. París cae desde arriba. Después de alcanzar al menos los cuartos de final de las últimas seis ediciones, el Paris Saint-Germain quedó eliminado en la segunda ronda preliminar de la Liga de Campeones femenina al perder 2-1 contra la Juventus de Turín el jueves en el campus del PSG en Poissy. Las parisinas ya habían sido derrotadas en el partido de ida (3-1). Es un revés para la sección femenina y sus estrellas, en particular sus internacionales francesas Elisa De Almeida, Gridge Mbock, Sakina Karchaoui, Grace Geyoro y Marie-Antoinette Katoto. Los jugadores de Fabrice Abriel, que se perdieron el primer tiempo, se quedaron helados al inicio del partido con un gol de Sofia Cantore (3º). Más emprendedoras tras el descanso, empataron con un penalti de la holandesa Romee Leuchter (54.º), pero Barbara Bonensea devolvió la ventaja a las turinesas (72.º). Francia sólo tendrá como representante en la C1 esta temporada al Lyon, finalista de 2023 y plusmarquista de victorias con 8 trofeos.

author: Anonym
title: Essequibo: Venezuela sends troops to border, Guyana says it has 'no plan' for attack - Teller Report
text: Essequibo: Venezuela sends troops to border, Guyana says it has 'no plan' for attack In the midst of the crisis over Essequibo, an oil-rich territory claimed by Venezuela, some 5,600 Venezuelan troops are taking part in military exercises of a "defensive" nature ordered Thursday by President Nicolas Maduro in "response to the provocation and threat of the United Kingdom," which has sent a warship to Guyana. Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro meets with staff at the Ministry of Defense in Caracas, Dec. 28, 2023. © Jhonn Zerpa/Miraflores Palace/Handout via REUTERS By: RFI Follow Advertising Read More As the two Latin American countries vie over the Essequibo region, interference from the United Kingdom, of which Guyana has long been a colony, is seen as a provocation to Venezuela. On Sunday 24 December, London announced the deployment of a military patrol ship, HMS Trent. In response, Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro announced on Thursday, December 28, a "defensive" military action by Venezuela in the face of the "threat" of a British ship in Guyana. In total, more than 5,600 Venezuelan soldiers have been taking part in military manoeuvres of a "defensive" nature since Thursday, December 28. "I have ordered the activation of a joint action of all the [Venezuelan] Bolivarian National Armed Forces in the Eastern Caribbean, on the Atlantic coast, a joint action of a defensive nature, in response to the provocation and threat of the United Kingdom against the peace and sovereignty of our country," President Maduro said during a radio and television broadcast. in which he showed images of warships and fighter jets patrolling the area. Read alsoEssequibo: "the effects of the announcement have not been followed by effects" Tensions have been exacerbated for several months For his part, Guyana's Vice President, Bharrat Jagdeo, is trying to ease tensions with his words. "We have no plan to take offensive measures against Venezuela... We have no intention of invading Venezuela. President Maduro knows this and should not be worried," he told a news conference. He also said the arrival of a British patrol boat in Guyana's waters was part of "routine exercises that have been planned for a long time". This territorial dispute, which has existed since 1899, has returned to the forefront of the news with the launch, last September, of oil tenders by Guyana, followed by the referendum held on 3 December in Venezuela on a proposal to annex Essequibo. This 160,000 km2 territory, rich in oil and natural resources, administered by Georgetown but claimed by Venezuela, covers two-thirds of Guyana's land area. It is home to about 125,000 people, or one-fifth of the country's population. Read alsoVenezuela-Guyana: could the crisis degenerate into conflict? (With AFP) NewsletterGet all the latest international news straight to your inbox Subscribe now Keep up to date with all the latest international news by downloading the RFI app Share: Read on the same topics: - Venezuela - Guyana - United Kingdom - Defense

author: Holdenyjra
title: Online Money Making By Composing E-Books
text:
Although publishing the old way is hard, you can self release your method to success. The big mistake individuals make is believing that there is an easy method to make a book effective, but the facts are that composing and promoting any book, consisting of one for kids is a very uphill struggle.
Invest the time you require to prepare an outline for your book, and after that devote an hour every day to the writing process. I have actually written 10 books in this way, and each one took me about four months to finish. Once your summary is detailed enough it just ends up being a process of filling out the blanks with your understanding and info.
To prosper, you require a tutor you can rely on when you struck the inescapable snags. The author of that book is still around and now provides tutoring service but he will remain unnamed as I have no interest

On the other hand I also took a look at books. And recognized that books ranged from novelty and executive length all the way approximately tomes. So comparing writing various length books was going to be a problem.
You only understand how excellent a book seeks you've written it. So a book is product centric. The entire focus is on the item, and it's coming out of your head. The marketing genius is not being acknowledged. Hear the marketing genius is your reader.

This book walks you step by step, day by day, as you compose the book you didn't understand you could compose. While you can make a decent living on the web by just selling other individuals's products, you will do a lot much better by producing your own product. Selling anything on the internet is hard and that is why the majority of individuals do not succeed.
After reading this list, you most likely realize you have some of the "composing as a pastime" mindset. Now that you're conscious of it, eliminate it. No more reasons. Make today the first day of the rest of your professional composing profession!
